*[Bug 15654] WISH/ROBUSTNESS: R CMD check for non-named '...' arguments to NextMethod()*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=15654>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|NEW                         |CLOSED
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
         Resolution|---                         |Works as documented

--- Comment #4 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
This works as documented and hence probably as intended, and the behavior
doesn't seem obviously broken to me. Arguments to NextMethod (other than
generic and object), can be used to modify the call by patching arguments (via
name matching, so using a name) or by appending new arguments (named or
unnamed). I've added a note suggested by Mikael to the documentation to make it
explicit that unnamed arguments are also appended to the end of the argument
list, but I think it already implied from the previous version of the
documentation.

One could easily argue that the feature of adding new arguments could be
useful, Mikael provided one example here.

Suggesting to change a core language functionality based on speculation that
certain use is always an error is something that cannot be accepted. The
minimum would be to actually turn this into error, test on all CRAN and
Bioconductor packages, debug all the cases that will be broken by it and
analyze them case-by-case. One could then report all the issues to the package
maintainers and propose to fixes in their packages, and that part could be
useful. But, even if all packages broken by this change were in fact due to an
error in the package, the case for change would still be rather weak - the
current, documented behavior, could in principle be useful and be legitimately
used by other code, not in the two repositories. The language, and even more so
its core part as the S3 system behavior, should be as stable as possible -
unlikely people would want to use a language that changes all the time.

text:
*[Bug 18875] NextMethod() duplicates positional arguments in the next method*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18875>

Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
         Resolution|---                         |Works as documented
                 CC|                            |tomas.kalibera@gmail.com
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED

--- Comment #3 from Tomas Kalibera (<mailto:tomas.kalibera@gmail.com|tomas.kalibera@gmail.com>) ---
The behavior of how extra arguments passed to NextMethod() can be used to patch
the call is as documented, is not obviously wrong, and could in principle be
useful. From my reading of the documentation, it is intentional. I've made this
more explicit in the documentation, see Bug 15654 for more, but it implied from
the documentation even before that.

If you have a question how to solve a specific problem in a package (involving
S3/NetxMethod), I would recommend you take it back to the mailing list.

Still, I don't see a reason to pass arguments like "x=x" to NextMethod(). I
assume you wanted modify the value of the corresponding argument in the call,
so e.g. do something like "x = x + 1"? If that is the case, and if you
understandably wanted to make this work regardless of whether "x" was passed
positionally or by name, you can do

foo.C <- function(x, y = 3, ...) {
    x <- x + 1
    NextMethod()
}

This works by design and is documented as well.

As a meta comment, while I don't see and R bug here, the NextMethod() behavior
and argument patching is something not commonly seen in other programming
languages, and is rather complicated. Defensively, I would avoid using such
features when easily possible, in the interest of maintainability.

*[Bug 18843] `as.data.frame()` method for objects of class `"lm"` and `"glm"` [with patch]*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18843>

--- Comment #8 from Thomas Soeiro (<mailto:Thomas.SOEIRO@ap-hm.fr|Thomas.SOEIRO@ap-hm.fr>) ---
In response to comment 6:

> Well, we can already do
```
lm(breaks ~ wool * tension, warpbreaks) |> summary() |> coefficients() |>
as.data.frame()
```

This does not return confidence intervals (as expected with `coefficients()`):
```
                Estimate Std. Error   t value     Pr(>|t|)
(Intercept)     44.55556   3.646761 12.217842 2.425903e-16
woolB          -16.33333   5.157299 -3.167032 2.676803e-03
tensionM       -20.55556   5.157299 -3.985721 2.280796e-04
tensionH       -20.00000   5.157299 -3.877999 3.199282e-04
woolB:tensionM  21.11111   7.293523  2.894501 5.698287e-03
woolB:tensionH  10.55556   7.293523  1.447251 1.543266e-01
```

My main point is to provide a helper to collect model statistics in a data
frame (i.e. estimates *and* confidence interval, along with the statistics
returned by `summary()`, as requested by other r-core members). This is useful
e.g. for exporting model statistics or plotting. Currently we need something
like:

```
fit <- lm(breaks ~ wool * tension, warpbreaks)

cf <- fit |> summary() |> coef()
ci <- confint(fit)
df <- data.frame(row.names(cf), cf, ci, row.names = NULL)
names(df) <- c("term", "estimate", "std.error", "statistic", "p.value",
"conf.low", "conf.high")
df
#             term  estimate std.error statistic      p.value   conf.low 
conf.high
# 1    (Intercept)  44.55556  3.646761 12.217842 2.425903e-16  37.223250 
51.887861
# 2          woolB -16.33333  5.157299 -3.167032 2.676803e-03 -26.702779 
-5.963888
# 3       tensionM -20.55556  5.157299 -3.985721 2.280796e-04 -30.925001
-10.186110
# 4       tensionH -20.00000  5.157299 -3.877999 3.199282e-04 -30.369445 
-9.630555
# 5 woolB:tensionM  21.11111  7.293523  2.894501 5.698287e-03   6.446501 
35.775721
# 6 woolB:tensionH  10.55556  7.293523  1.447251 1.543266e-01  -4.109055 
25.220166
```

I understand that `as.data.frame()` methods may not be the best way. Here is an
attempt to summarise what has been discussed:

| interface | pros | cons |
| - | - | - |
| `as.data.frame(lm(.))` | short | not explicit (see comment 4) |
| `as.data.frame(summary(lm(.)))` or `summary(lm(.), data.frame = TRUE)` | more
explicit ? | `summary.lm()` does not return confidence intervals, so returning
it in the data frame is counterintuitive |
| `collect_stats(lm(.))` | short and can be explicit if function name is good
enough | ? |

*[Bug 18550] ignore 'nonS3methods' when reexported*
<https://bugs.r-project.org/show_bug.cgi?id=18550>

Sebastian Meyer (<mailto:seb.meyer@fau.de|seb.meyer@fau.de>) changed:

           What    |Removed                     |Added
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
             Status|UNCONFIRMED                 |CLOSED
                 CC|                            |seb.meyer@fau.de
         Resolution|---                         |FIXED
            Summary|Please accept a patch to    |ignore 'nonS3methods' when
                   |classify a reexported       |reexported
                   |function as non-S3-method   |

--- Comment #10 from Sebastian Meyer (<mailto:seb.meyer@fau.de|seb.meyer@fau.de>) ---
`tools::checkS3methods()` has been extensively rewritten in r83941 (R >= 4.3.0)
"to look for generics in the right place, and also find possible issues with
GEN.CLS matches." The new code to determine
`methods_not_registered_with_exported_generic` only considers methods in the
package's own namespace (`functions_in_code`) and thus no longer matches and
NOTEs imported "apparent S3 methods". With R 4.2.3, `tools::checkS3methods`
would output
```
Found the following apparent S3 methods exported but not registered:
  as.mcmc.list
```
for a package that reexports both `as.mcmc` and `as.mcmc.list` from 'coda'. I
verified that this no longer happens in R >= 4.3.0 (which also needs
environment variable `_R_CHECK_S3_METHODS_SHOW_POSSIBLE_ISSUES_` set to a true
value to enable the check).
